resources.string:
The village of Castell lies near the romnatic forest range of the Steigerwald in Unterfanken (lower Franconion), Germany. It is also the seat of the noble dynasty of "Castell". 
 
The village has a long standing tradition of viticulture. Some of Franconians finest wines are pressed in the Domänenamt of Castell, the vineyard estate owned by the noble dynasty of Castell. 
 
Castell delights its visitors with beautiful landscapes, traditional Franconian dishes and of course the extraordinary wine, and enthralls friends of culture and history with historical sides and a wide array of concerts and other cultural events.

The \"new\" castle of Castell is the current seat of the noble dynasty of Castell-Castell. The building works started in 1687 and were finished in 1691. It is a three winged structure in the style of the early baroque.

The Town Hall of Castell was built in 1848. Originally, it was the local school building. In the upper stocks, lessons were held up till 1969. Since 1978 it serves not only for as the town hall for Castell, but also for the incorporated communes Greuth and Wüstenfelden. The backside of the building is home of a home museum.

The \"Comital Castell-Remlingen\'sche Country Credit-Casa\" of Castell was founded by Friedrich Adolph von Zwanziger in 1774. It was originally a welfare institution intended to help the impoverished farmers in the area with favourable credits as well as fighting the usury in the county. \n It was then transformed into the \"Princely Castell Bank\" during the 19th and 20th century. It is considered the oldes Bavarian bank and one of the few banks in private ownership, belonging to the dynasty of Castell.

The evangelic-lutheran church St. Johannes is one of the oldest churches in the area. It was first mentioned in the 13th century. The current building was completed in 1792. The outside structure is held in the style of the late baroque, while the inner building is dominated by the classicism.
The "Princely Archive of Castell" stores over 8000 documents from about the villages of the county Castell from 1224 to the 20th century.

The old Castle Tower is the last standing remnant of the old fortress and castle of the counts of Castell-Castell. They where not build within village, but on two hills rising over the settlement: the Herrenberg (lords\' hill) and the Schloßberg (castle\'s hill).

Castell is a famous for its fine wines. The grapes cultivated in the vineyards around the village are mainly the typical Franconian varieties like Müller-Thurgau, Bacchus, Riesling, Domani and of course Silvaner, the traditionally most important grape of the area. A documents from 1659 implies that the first Franconian Silvaner was planted in Castell. \n A lot, but not all of the wine, are filled in Bocksbeutel, a traditional Franconian form for wine bottles.
There are seven vineyard sites surrounding Castell: Schlossberg, Reitsteig, Kirchberg, Trautberg, Hohnart, Kugelspiel and Bausch. The soil consists mainly out of clay and gypsum-keuper.

The bright yellow Weinbergstulpe is a flower that can be found in the vineyards around Castell. It blooms in bright yellows. In the spring, the people of Castell hold a feast to celebrated it, called \"Weinbergstulpenfest\".
The inn \"Zum Schwan\" (to the swan) offers traditional Franconian cuisine, wine and rooms for guests.
The restaurant "Weinstall" has been build in the stables of the new castle. It offers finest Franconian cuisine as well as wine from Castell.
The tavern "Grüner Baum" offers only drinks and is a meeting place for locals.

The Kniebrecher is a café and bistro. It offers food and drinks and is a popular meeting place for the locals. Its nem, which means \"knee breaker\" comes from the steep incline at which start it lies.

The \"Kerm\" is a traditional fair in Franconian held to celebrate the benediction of the local church. In Castell, the Kerm takes place in the autumn and lasts for several days. An important part of it is the so called \"Kirchweihrede\" during which the young men of the village tell short stories and perform plays about funny occurrences that happened to the people over the year.

At the 30th of April, the young men of Castell erect the May Tree. It is traditionally a tall, slender birch with red-white ribbons in its crown. When the tree has been erected, it has to be guarded as the young people from the surrounding villages will try to steal each others trees. If a tree is successfully stolen, the young people who couldn\'t defend their tree have to pay a ransom of beer.

In 2016 Castell celebrated its 1200 anniversary. The pinnacle of the celebration was a Medieval Market including a knight\'s festival performed by the stunt crew \"Geyers Enkel\" of the Florian-Geyer-Spiele in Giebelstadt.

The Gründleinsloch is a well outside the village of Castell. Known for its mysterious blue water, it is the center of many local legends. 
 
One of the most famous tells of three young women visiting the feasts in the castle, enticing the young men with their beauty and grace, but always leaving before midnight. 
When some of the young men set the clock of the church tower at the wrong time to trick them into staying longer, they flee in panic as they hear the bell ring midnight. 
The young men follow them and watch them running down to the well and throwing themselves inside it. However, once the young men themselves reach the well, they see to their horror a swirl of blood rising to the surface. The three young maidens never returned.

The Blue Woman is a guardian spirit of the dynasty of Castell-Castell. 
 
Once a countess of Castell herself, she told her husband who was going to war that should he suffer great misery and knew now other way, he should look towards his home in the west during sundown and say her name three times. As the count becomes a captive rotting away in a forgotten prison of the enemy, he finally can't bear being separated from his family anymore, he calls his wife's name during sundown and is freed by a magical blue light that opens his chains, makes his guardians fall asleep and guides him to a pegasus which carries him home. 
When he arrives at home, however, everyone is grieving. Entering the castle, he learns that last night at sundown his wife sat at the window, looking eastwards as she suddenly whispered "I'm coming" and fell dead to the floor. 
 
Later, during the peasants war, the blue woman appeared again. In a dream she showed the son of the count in the besieged castle a secret passage through which he could flee with his siblings and his mother. 
 
Source: "Zwischerlichten" by Teophil Steinbrenner, Gerhard Wahler, Auguste Steinberger and Felix von Fokczynski.
